title: Basic Router Configuration
description: Understanding router configuration modes, commands, and basic device setup

keyConcepts.title: Router Boot Process
keyConcepts.description: Router performs POST, loads bootstrap from ROM, locates and loads IOS from Flash, then loads startup-config from NVRAM into RAM as running-config. If no startup-config exists, router enters setup mode.

keyConcepts.title: CLI Access Modes
keyConcepts.description: User EXEC mode (>) provides limited monitoring. Privileged EXEC mode (#) provides full access to all commands. Global configuration mode (config)# allows device-wide settings. Specific config modes (line, interface) configure particular features.

keyConcepts.title: Password Security
keyConcepts.description: Console and VTY lines use 'password' + 'login' commands. Enable password provides basic protection. Enable secret uses MD5 hashing for stronger security and overrides enable password. Service password-encryption obscures plain-text passwords with Type 7 encryption.

keyConcepts.title: Configuration Files
keyConcepts.description: Running-config is active configuration stored in RAM (volatile). Startup-config is saved configuration stored in NVRAM (non-volatile). Use 'copy running-config startup-config' to save changes permanently.

keyConcepts.title: Interface Configuration
keyConcepts.description: Interfaces must be configured with IP addresses and enabled with 'no shutdown'. Use 'show ip interface brief' to verify interface status and IP configuration.

keyConcepts.title: Default Gateway
keyConcepts.description: The logical IP address of the router's local interface. Hosts use this address to send packets destined for remote networks.

importantPoints: Router enters setup mode when startup-config is missing from NVRAM
User EXEC mode prompt: Router>
Privileged EXEC mode prompt: Router#
Global config mode prompt: Router(config)#
Line config mode prompt: Router(config-line)#
Interface config mode prompt: Router(config-if)#
Command 'enable' enters privileged EXEC mode
Command 'configure terminal' enters global configuration mode
Command 'hostname <name>' changes the device name
Console access = out-of-band management (physical connection)
VTY access = in-band management (Telnet/SSH over network)
'enable secret' is more secure than 'enable password' (uses MD5)
'service password-encryption' encrypts all plain-text passwords with Type 7
Type 7 encryption is weak and reversible (not secure)
'banner motd' displays message to all users who connect
'show ip interface brief' shows all interfaces with IP and status
RAM stores: running-config, routing table, ARP cache
NVRAM stores: startup-config (persistent)
Flash stores: Cisco IOS image
ROM stores: bootstrap program and POST
'copy running-config startup-config' saves configuration
Default gateway is the IP address of the local router interface
'login' command must be used in line mode to prompt for password
Interfaces are administratively down by default - use 'no shutdown'
